revisions.*: Because "rvslots" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used.

{{Taxobox | image = Agaricus alberti.JPG | image_width = 234px | image_caption = | regnum = [[Fungi]] | divisio = [[Basidiomycota]] | classis = [[Agaricomycetes]] | ordo = [[Agaricales]] | familia = [[Agaricaceae]] | genus = ''[[Agaricus]]'' | species = '''''A. macrosporus''''' | binomial = ''Agaricus macrosporus'' | binomial_authority = ([[F.H.Møller]] & [[Jul.Schff.]]) Pilát (1951) | synonyms_ref = | synonyms = ''Psalliota arvensis'' subsp. ''macrospora'' F.H.Møller & Jul.Schäff. (1938)
''Psalliota macrospora'' (F.H.Møller & Jul.Schäff.) F.H.Møller (1951)
''Agaricus albertii'' [[Marcel Bon|Bon]] (1988) }} {{mycomorphbox | name = ''Agaricus macrosporus'' | whichGills = free | capShape = convex | hymeniumType=gills | stipeCharacter=ring | ecologicalType= | sporePrintColor=purple-brown |sporePrintColor2= | howEdible=edible}} '''''Agaricus macrosporus''''' is a rare, [[edible mushroom]] found from June at wood fringes and in meadows. ==Description== The white [[Pileus (mycology)|cap]] is hemispherical and white when young, but later flattens out up to 25 cm in diameter and becomes yellowish or tan. Its [[Trama (mycology)|flesh]] is very thick. The [[Gill (mycology)|gills]] are pinkish grey when young, and become brown with age. The [[spore]]s measure 12 by 6 [[Micrometer|μm]] and are purplish-brown and almond-shaped. The [[Stipe (mycology)|stem]] is strong and thick, with a broad ring. It may measure 8 to 12 cm in height and up to 3 cm in diameter. The flesh is white with a mild taste and a smell of aniseed, turning slowly orange when cut. ==Similar species== There is a danger of confusing this mushroom with the deadly poisonous bulbous agaric ''[[Amanita phalloides]]'' and ''[[Amanita pantherina]]''. ''[[Agaricus excellens]]'' is different by its taller and slimmer stipe which is striped lengthwise. ''[[Agaricus augustus]]'' does not have the pure white cap in young specimens. ==See also== [[List of Agaricus species|List of ''Agaricus'' species]] ==References== {{Reflist|refs= {{cite web |title=''Agaricus macrosporus'' (F.H. Møller & Jul. Schäff.) Pilát 1951 |url=http://www.mycobank.org/MycoTaxo.aspx?Link=T&Rec=292286 |publisher=[[MycoBank]]. International Mycological Association |accessdate=2012-02-10}} }} *{{cite book|title=The Mushrooms and Toadstools of Britain and North Western Europe |last= Bon |first=Marcel |authorlink= Marcel Bon |year=1987 | publisher= Hodder and Stoughton |isbn = 0-340-39935-X}} *E. Garnweidner. ''Mushrooms and Toadstools of Britain and Europe''. Collins. 1994. {{Taxonbar|from=Q2249479}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Agaricus Macrosporus}} [[Category:Agaricus|macrosporus]] [[Category:Edible fungi]] [[Category:Fungi of Europe]]
